area_name: Cirque of the Climbables - Right Side

content.description: A steep finger crack leads to a knobby hand crack.  The finger crack is very nice, but short.  The hand crack has some nice moves, but fractured rock in places is a concern.  There are two 5.10A moves, one on the lower finger crack and one going over a bulge on the hand crack.
content.location: This climb is near the right end of the cliff, but well to the left of Christmas Tree Arete.  See the photo in the Vogel guide.

climbs.name: Poodle Pot Pie
climbs.fa: Karen Roseme, Mary Anne Kelly and Chris Miller, November 1997

content.description: Climb the featured crack that splits the block up and left from the arete. Another fun moderate climb on good plated rock makes this one one star out of five.
content.location:
Located on the right side of the Cirque of the Climbables just left of the

Christmas Tree Arete

.

climbs.name: Peer Pressure
climbs.fa: Rex Pieper, Jeff Thomas and Keath Nupuf, April 1994

content.description:
Climb a crack that turns to more of a seam at the crux - a bulging section that requires some delicate face moves above tiny wires. The gear is good and the moves positive, although getting the gear in is problematic.

A really fun, but unfortunately short, route that leaves one wishing the pitch was a little longer. Well worth doing in in the area when combined with some of the nearby starred routes. Two stars out of five.
content.protection: Gear to 2.5 inches, include tiny wires
content.location:
Located just down and right from the

Christmas Tree Arete

. The climb is visible in the Vogel guide as a dogleg crack/seam that splits a dark and light-colored face.

content.description:
Fun for the whole family... if parents are down with kids doing a traverse that is unprotected.  A blocky start to a dike feature continues through a positive leftward traverse without pro.  Mostly good rock, but beware at least one loose hold.  The traverse ends with an arete that becomes more exposed up high just before the finish.

Almost merits the name Black Tide.
content.protection: A pink tricam lowered an unsure follower just fine before they started the traverse.  A few so-so chickenhead tie-offs on the arete plus small to medium nuts did the job.  Thin to medium nuts plus medium cams for the anchor.
content.location: Descend the easy gully to the left.

climbs.name: Christmas Tree Arete
climbs.fa: Rob Stahl, Dave Evans, Craig Fry &  Tom Burke, January 1990

content.description: This is a steep, strenuous face route with some rounded holds.  We found it necessary to use a foothold on the pinyon tree at the base of the climb to get started.
content.location: This is near the right end of the Cirque of the Climbables, and is shown on a photo in the 1992 Vogel guide.  It follows a rounded arete at the right end of one part of the formation.

content.description: Climb the face up the center of the formation which is steep for a section before kicking back towards the top. The climbing is on heavily featured solid rock with occasional protection. Fun climbing and easier than first appearances might suggest. One star out of five.
content.location:
Located on the formation immediately right of

Peer Pressure

, which in turn lies just down and right from the Christmas Tree Arete.

pathTokens: Cirque of the Climbables - Right Side
